g.text: "Finding layout families without comparing every pair"
✓ Sub-linear query time: O(log N) or O(1)
✓ Low memory: O(K) where K = cluster count
✓ High recall: find >95% of true matches
2. Pages with same hash → same bucket
Add similarity layer on top for fuzzy clustering.
2. Hash shingles with multiple hash functions
3. Keep min hash per function → signature
Process each page as it arrives:
• If distance < threshold → assign to cluster
• Else → create new cluster with page as leader
Use hash-based pre-filter: only compare to clusters
where L1 hash matches OR LSH bands overlap.
Group at coarse level, split at fine level
Range: WHERE signature_hash BETWEEN → O(log N + k)
Query: pages sharing ANY band = candidates
Size: O(K) where K = cluster count (~100s)
Works on: shingle sets, MinHash signatures
Complexity: O(|A| + |B|) for sets, O(n) for MinHash
Works on: fixed-size bit vectors, SimHash
Complexity: O(1) with SIMD, O(w) for w words
• Hamming on L1 hash (8 bytes) → <5 bits = candidate
• Jaccard on MinHash (64 bytes) → actual similarity
Keep cluster centroids in memory (not on disk)
Cluster within domain first (layouts are domain-specific)
Cross-domain clustering only for template discovery
Stop searching once distance < threshold found
Order clusters by recency (likely matches first)
Average case: check 3-5 clusters, not all
Collect N signatures before clustering pass
N = total pages, K = cluster count, n = hash functions
Query = find cluster, Insert = add new page, Space = total storage
Fuzzy = handles similarity, Online = incremental updates
Exact hash for fast lookup → LSH for candidate filter →
Leader clustering for fuzzy assignment with O(K) memory
SELECT * FROM layout_signatures WHERE hash = L1
If distance < T: assign | Else: create new cluster
Best of all worlds: exact + fuzzy + incremental
